user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_Run:
```c
void UtTest_Run(void)
{
    UtListNode_t *         UtListMain;
    UtListNode_t *         UtListNode;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t *UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    /*
     * The overall test sequence goes SETUP->TEST->TEARDOWN
     *
     * Combine all registered test groups into a merged group for execution.
     *
     * This could also (theoretically) randomize the order of the "TEST" group
     * while assembling this list, if there was a portable source of entropy.
     */
    UtListMain = UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_DEFAULT);
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_SETUP));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEARDOWN));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    /*
     * Run through the merged list in order
     */
    for (UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListMain); !UtList_IsEnd(UtListMain, UtListNode);
         UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListNode))
    {
        UtTestDataBaseEntry = UtList_GetObject(UtListNode);

        if (UtTestDataBaseEntry != NULL)
        {
            UtAssert_BeginTest(UtTestDataBaseEntry->TestName);

            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup();
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test();
                UtAssert_Global.ExecutedCount++;
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown();
            }

            UtAssert_EndTest();
        }
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Destroy(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_EndTest(UtAssert_GetCounters());
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_Run:
bool UtList_IsEnd(UtListNode_t *TagHead, UtListNode_t *ListNode)
{
    return (TagHead == ListNode);
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetNext(UtListNode_t *ListNode)
{
    return ListNode->Next;
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
...
void UtList_Merge(UtListNode_t *TagHead1, UtListNode_t *TagHead2)
{
    UtListNode_t *Tail1 = TagHead1->Prev;
    UtListNode_t *Tail2 = TagHead2->Prev;

    Tail1->Next    = TagHead2;
    Tail2->Next    = TagHead1;
    TagHead1->Prev = Tail2;
    TagHead2->Prev = Tail1;
}
...
void *UtList_GetObject(UtListNode_t *ListNode)
{
    return ListNode->Data;
}
...
typedef struct UtListNodeTag
{
    struct UtListNodeTag *Next;
    struct UtListNodeTag *Prev;
    void *                Data;
    uint32                DataSize;
    uint32                Tag;
} UtListNode_t
...
typedef struct
{
    void (*Test)(void);
    void (*Setup)(void);
    void (*Teardown)(void);

    /* Note - the name entry should be long enough to support a GroupName.TestName pattern,
     * hence why it uses double the OS_MAX_API_NAME length */
    char TestName[OS_MAX_API_NAME * 2];
} UtTestDataBaseEntry_t
...
UtAssert_Global_t UtAssert_Global
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I have reported the controlling expressions that could be invariant or that contribute directly to loop/selection control and therefore should be inspected for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Other expressions and statements in the provided code were not included because they do not form controlling expressions (e.g. simple assignments, function calls that do not act as loop/selection conditions) or they obviously depend on runtime-modifiable data (e.g. pointer dereferences that obtain data from list nodes, increments of global counters, calls that set context). These runtime-dependent expressions cannot be considered invariant without additional global/static analysis of the data structures, so they are not flagged here. Also, there are no do-while loops or deliberate infinite-loop constructs in the provided code that would fall under the stated exceptions to the rule.
